landingPages.title: Welcome
landingPages.question: Socket cannot be held responsible for any damages or injuries.

landingPages.title: Welcome
landingPages.question: Carefully read and follow all instructions.  Many mechanical problems are solved with simple solutions.

pages.title: Lets Begin!
pages.question: Ensure both engine switch and choke are in the on position. Turn the key or use the pull cord. Does the engine start?

pages.title: Not starting
pages.question: OK,Is it an electric start or a pull cord?

pages.title: Not starting
pages.question: Ok, go ahead and give it another try.  Does the engine turn?

pages.title: Not starting
pages.question: Please ensure that all engine safeties are engaged'Pressing the brakes, mower is off,transmission is in neutral etc'

pages.title: Battery
pages.question: OK, let's take a quick look at the battery.  You will need a voltmeter for the next few steps

pages.title: Battery
pages.question: Touch the voltmeter prods on the appropriate battery terminals.  Is it reading 12V?

pages.title: Battery
pages.question: Charge or replace battery

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: Ok, now we need to locate the starter. 'Be careful around the starter terminals as the power one is always live.'

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: You will need a voltmeter.  Place the positive VM prod on the red starter terminal and ground the neg prod on solid steel or battery negative terminal.  Is is reading 12V or Higher?

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: The starter to battery cable is cut, frayed or disconnected.

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: OK, Lets get into some electrical.  A test light might help. Ground the test light onto the frame. Press the test light onto the starter solenoid terminal 'smaller wires' Again, attempt to start the engine. Does the light illuminate when the key is turned?

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: Ok, The problem is most likely a loose connection, broken or cut wire somewhere between the battery and the starter

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: Hmm, you might need a new starter or solenoid.  Did you know you can bench test a starter!

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: We will be putting he battery to work so make sure you keep it charged through the troubleshooting process.

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Here we go!  A few things worth mentioning before we beginDuring our trouble shooting stage, please keep hands clear of moving parts, use common sense and be safe

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: OK!  Any engine needs,fuel,spark,compression,timing,Its that simple

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Lets start with spark as its the quickest to verify

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Lets go ahead and remove the spark plug boots. Now remove the plugs from the cylinder. Re-attach spark plugs to the boots.  Ground the spark plug ends to the engine or frame.'Steel'

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: WARNING! Wedge the spark plugs so that you donâ€™t need to hold them in place as you can experience electrical shock. Or you can wear rubber gloves

pages.title: Ignition Electrical
pages.question: Go ahead and turn the key.  As the engine rotates, look for constant spark at the spark plug end.  A strong blue spark is a great spark.  A weak yellow spark is worst and may lead to misfires.  Is the spark blue and constant?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Is there any spark ?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Do you have a points system?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: On both spark plugs?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Alright, there is intermittent or weak spark on both spark plugs.  Do you have a points system?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Gotcha.  I think we should open the points box.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: A good telltale sign of worn out points is blue arcing in the points box.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: As you crank over the engine, can you see any signs of arcing in the points box?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: If you see any arcing, that is most likely the problem.  Try adjusting the points gap first.  If that did not fix it, remove and replace the condenser and points system.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Ok, I'm leaning towards a bad spark plug wire.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Swap the spark plug wires.  Does the other spark plug work now?

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Remove and replace spark plug wires.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: You have a broken spark plug.

pages.title: Testing Spark
pages.question: Ok, You're probably looking at a weak or bad coil.

pages.title: Incomplete
pages.question: Were sorry, this app isn't finished

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Good enough, please re-install the spark plug and attach the boots. Fuel, sparkâ€”â€”â€” 'Scratched out', compression, timing

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Fuel is the most common cause of small engine failure.  Lets begin!

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Do you have gas?!  Please visually check.  We're not kidding.  This happens all the time.  Add some, why not! Did that fix it?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Ok, Is the fuel petcock valve closed?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Hmm, Lets go in deeper.  WARNING! Fuel is flammable.  Don't smoke nearby during these steps.  Keep a glass fuel jar handy as well as a few rags

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Shut off fuel petcock valve.  Follow the fuel line from the gas tank all the way to the engine carburetor.  Unplug the fuel line at the carburetor end.  If you have a fuel pump, disconnect it there.  Put the fuel line end in a glass jar and make sure it is lower then the gas tank as this test is relies on gravity

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Go ahead and open up the petcock fuel valve.  As long as the jar is lower then the gas tank, there should be a good fuel flow.  You can now close the petcock fuel valve.  Was there good fuel flow ?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Good news, this is most likely and easy fix.  Reasons you donâ€™t have good fuel flow might be -gas cap vent 'remove the gas cap and retry the last test' -broken petcock valve' remove and replace' -clogged or picked fuel line'remove and replace' -clogged fuel filter'remove and replace' -bottom of your gas tank is clogged 'empty gas and wash out the tank with fuel'

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Ok, Do you have a fuel pump?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Fuel pumps work one of three ways.  Electrical pumps work off the battery.  Mechanical and vacuum pump work off the engines rotation.  Which one do you have?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Mechanical and vacuum pumps.  Disconnect the fuel pump at the carb.  Put the fuel line in a glass jar.  Turn the key'start' to get the engine turning and observe that the is fuel spurting in the jar

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Electrical fuel pump.  Disconnect the fuel line at the carb.  Put the fuel line in a glass jar.  Turn the key to the on position,  you should hear the fuel pump priming and see fuel flow

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Is there good fuel flow?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Replace or Rebuild the fuel pump.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Reconnect the fuel lines.  On to the Carburator!

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: A carburetor can seem intimidating but its a fairly simple system.  Just remember to keep everything clean.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Find the Carburetor, Find the Carburetor bowl.  With a rag in hand, Unscrew the drain screw or plug on the bowl.  There wonâ€™t be much fuel, depending on engine size 1 to 2 ounces.  Its also a good idea to take note of the fuel colour. Is there fuel dripping out?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Hmm, Im going to guess that the carburetors float needle is stuck.  You should clean the carb and replace all gaskets with new ones.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Ok, we're almost ready to scratch fuel from our list.  Lets quickly perform a intake vacuum test before we move on.  Did you know engines use air vacuums for many things?  One of the vacuum systems is responsible for fuel delivery in the cylinders

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Lets give this a try.  Remove the air filter along with the air box.  With the palm of your hand, fully block the intake port.  Then the key (Start position) .  While engine is turning, listen carefully.  Do you hear a high pitch whistle?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: You have an intake vacuum leak.  This must be located and fixed before diagnosing further as it causes undesirable symptoms.

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: Ok, last fuel related test.  With all fuel lines conected, turn key to the start position for 5 sec.  Now quickly remove the spark plugs.  Touch and smell the spark plug.  Is the spark plug end wet?  Does it smell like fuel?

pages.title: Testing Fuel
pages.question: If you have good fuel flow from the gas tank to the carb.  And if you donâ€™t have an intake leak.  Then we must assume the carb is the culprit.  -Remove and clean, rebuild or replace carb.  The jets might be clogged.  Gasket might be ripped

pages.title: Engine troubleshooting
pages.question: Ok, Good enough.  We have to assume fuel system works.  On to the next Fuel â€”â€”'scratched out'.  Sparkâ€”'scratched out'.  Compression.  Timing.  On to compression!

pages.title: Testing Compression
pages.question: We will need a compression gauge for this next test.  Disconnect and remove the spark plugs.  Screw the gauge fitting into the cylinder head.  Be sure to use the correct fitting as it could damage piston head.  If unsure, you can slowly turn engine by hand using the flywheel,  two complete rotation to insure piston full travel

pages.title: Testing Compression
pages.question: Turn the key ,Start Position, for 3 seconds.  Read the gauge and take note.  Repeat process on other cylinder.

pages.title: Testing Compression
pages.question: Compare readings to your engine specs.  As a general rule of thumb, A cylinder with compression rating between 90 and 110 PSI will work.  Are the cylinder pressures in range?

pages.title: Testing Compression
pages.question: Aha!  Reasons for low compression.  Blown head gasket.  Stuck or sticking valves.  Scored cylinder.  Piston rings

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Compression checks out!  Fuelâ€”'scratched out' .  Sparkâ€”'scratched out'.  Compressionâ€”'scratched out'. Timing

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: We will need a timing light for this test.  Small engines have timing marks on the flywheel.  These can be tricky to find, but they are there.

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: Once located, connect the timing light.  One lead to the positive terminal of the battery.  The other between the spark plug and the boot.  Turn the key to the start position.  You may need someone to do this for you

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: Point the light to the timing mark.  As the light flashes along with engine rotation, the timing marks should be aligned.  Are the marks Aligned?

pages.title: Engine Troubleshooting
pages.question: Timing is correct.  Sparkâ€”'scratched out'.  Fuelâ€”'scratched out'.  Compressionâ€”'scratched out'.  Timingâ€”'scratched out'.  We recommend starting this trouble shooting app.  The engine should start

pages.title: Testing Timing
pages.question: Ah!  Reasons engine timing is off could be.  Timing chain failure or wear.  Ignition time needs to be retarded or advanced

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Does the engine run for more then 20 seconds with the choke on?

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Slowly move the choke to the off position.  Is the engine still running?

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: Ok, This is most likely a fuel delivery problem.  More specifically a clogged Idle jet.  Remove the carb and clean, rebuild or replace.  If cleaning, take specific care in cleaning the jets, soaking them in cleaning solution for 12 hours, then carefully run wire through the jets and finally clean out with compressed air.

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Ok, Slowly moving up the throttle now.  Is it still running?

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Hmm, this could be one of 2 things.  Its most likely a fuel delivery problem.  More specifically a clogged Main jet.  Remove the carb and clean, rebuild or replace.  If cleaning, take specific care in cleaning the jets, soaking them in cleaning solution for 12 hours, then carefully run wire through the jets and finally clean out with compressed air. Did that fix it?

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Lets give this a try..  Wearing rubber gloves, while engine is running at idle, pull one of the spark plug boot off. The engine should still run on one cylinder.  Re-install the boot and perform task again on opposite cylinder spark plug boot. Did the engine keep running?

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: Were not sure what is going on.  Check back with us as we are always improving this app.  We suggest you restart the process.  The engine should work

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: If the engine died when you pulled off a spark plug boot, then the opposite spark plug is the culprit reasons why can be.  Bad spark plug.  Bad spark plug wire.  Bad coil

pages.title: Engine Tune Up
pages.question: Is the engine RPM surging up and down?

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: An engine that is surging up and down is usually suffering from a bad carburator adjustment and or improperly gaped spark plugs.  There are two screws that help with carburetor adjustment.  An idle screw and the other a mixture screw. Together they can help with the surging RPM.  Also ensure the spark plugs are well gaped by using a filler gauge

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: Where not sure whats wrong with your engine

pages.title: OK. Is it electrical start or pull cord?
pages.question: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Maecenas id dolor odio. Pellentesque habitant morbi tristique senectus et netus et malesuada fames ac turpis egestas.

pages.title: Engine Tuning
pages.question: Ok, This is most likely a fuel delivery problem.  More specificaly a stuck needle or a badly adjusted float.
